div.p: IV:45. I began the year with invocation to the father of mercies, for virtue and wisdom; and if it be consistent with his Providence, for prosperity— I spent the morning in my chamber at my usual occupation of writing— I am yet examining the Laws of the several States of the Union, upon weights and measures, and this has given me the occasion for a cursory inspection of the Edition now in the process of publication of the Statutes at large of Virginia, from the first Settlement of the Colony— A work which I wish should be executed also in Massachusetts.— I had some conversation with my son George, concerning his future prospects and intentions— He inclines to the study of the Law; which concurs with my own wishes. As he told me his Class were to study the Federalist, at their next term, I have advised him to read it through here, during the vacation— He is undertaking also to be an early riser, and has good dispositions— Mrs Adams with Fanny Johnson and Mary Hellen, and I with Johnson Hellen, and my Sons George and John attended at the drawing room, at the President’s— It was more thronged with company, than I ever saw it on any similar occasion. “Donec eris felix, multos numerabis amicos.” Mr Monroe by a vote, with a single exception unanimous, of all the electoral Colleges of this Union, has just been re-elected President of the United States, for a second term of four years— No such state of things as the present has existed since the establishment of the present Constitution; for although the second election of Washington, like the first, was unanimous; yet the opposition to his administration was more organized and more violent, than it now is to that of Mr. Monroe. After the drawing-room was over I attended at my Office— Captain O’Brien called there. He is still soliciting of the Committee of Claims for an explanatory act in his favour, and the Chairman of the Committee has written to me, for my opinion in the case. I received a private Letter from John Forsyth our Minister at Madrid, informing me that the Cortes on the 5th. of October had advised, in secret Session the ratification of the Florida Treaty— The Letter is of the same day, and is the first direct information of the Event. It confirms that which had been received on the 16th. of last Month from R. Rush who had been notified of it by a private Letter from the Duke of Frías the Spanish Ambassador in London, on the 20th. of October— The rumour has been circulating here these five or six weeks, but it would scarcely seem credible that within four days, three months should elapse from the day of a transaction so important to us at Madrid, before any direct advice of it should come to us. It shews that Instructions should be given to the Representatives of the Public in Spain to transmit to us notice of all events of primary importance by the way of London and Liverpool— We had company to dine with us. S. W. Dana of Connecticut, and N. Van Dyke of Delaware, Senators— Philemon Beecher of Ohio, W. Eustis, Timothy Fuller, and Marcus Morton, of Massachusetts, Jonathan O. Moseley of Connecticut, Randall S. Street of New-York, members of the House of Representatives a son of Mr Van Dyke’s, and W. S. Smith— I had invited Mahlon Dickerson, a Senator from New-Jersey, John W. Taylor, Speaker of the House of Representatives Joshua Cushman, member of the House from Maine, and young Baring and Labouchère. Taylor accepted yesterday, but sent me an excuse this day, upon a plea of business— The rest were engaged. I gave most of the invitations at the Drawing-room this morning— We had a pleasant and cheerful party— In the Evening, after the rest of the company had retired the young people had a dance, and I made a party at Chess with W. S. Smith— The foreign Ministers paid us this Morning visits of form.

2. VI:30.Mr George Tucker, a member of the House of Representatives from Virginia came this morning and introduced at my house a young man by the name of Cabell, from that State— At the Office I made a Draft of a Report to the President, with the papers relating to the Slave-trade, called for by Resolution of the House of Representatives; and also of a Message from the President to the House, to communicate these papers— Mr. Canning, to whom I had sent my answer to his Note of 20. December on this subject, called at my Office, and we had a desultory Conversation of at least three hours, on the Slave-trade, the Queen’s trial, European Politics, Literature and indeed all sorts of topics. Concerning the Slave-trade, he expressed the opinion that the proposals in my note would be quite inadequate to the object proposed, the effectual suppression of the trade.
But he added his only remaining duty was to transmit them to his Government; which he should immediately do— He also enquired what amount of force it was contemplated by us, to keep, on the African Coast; what particular Instructions it was proposed to give in concert to the commanders, and in what manner it was supposed they might co-operate together— I told him the general instruction to co-operate, if agreed upon in principle by the two Governments, would lead to information from the Officers themselves upon which more particular instructions might afterwards be prepared. That for the present the Instruction to cruize in company together when they may find it useful, and to communicate information mutually as opportunities may offer, was all that was deemed advisable, but there could be no doubt that a more special concurrent exertion might hereafter be combined. It was very apparent that Mr Canning was in no wise satisfied with our proposed substitute; nor is it to be expected that his Government will be more so.— By the accounts just received from England it has been learnt that the Bill of Pains and Penalties against the Queen, has been abandoned in the House of Peers, after a vote by a majority of nine, that it should pass to a third reading. I told Mr Canning that I honoured his kinsman for the Independence of Spirit with which as a Minister he had refused to take part in the prosecution against the Queen; and the more so, as I was well aware of the conflict through which he must have passed in the cabinet, before he had come to that conclusion. I added that the issue had shewn that the course which he would have taken in that affair would have been the best, even with a view to the interest of the king— I made also many free remarks upon the proceedings in the house of Lords; upon the Speeches of the Chancellor, upon the temporizing and consciencious scruples of the Bishops, and upon the advantages taken of them by the opposition peers. Canning was as usual exceedingly cautious, to avoid expressing any opinion of his own; only by a sort of involuntary exclamation, saying that the trial of the Queen was to be sure “a very bad affair.” Of the rest, he said little; but admired the consummate ability of the Lord Chancellor’s Speech on the bills passing to the third reading— The rest of this Conversation were too tedious to detail; consisting altogether of my opinions, given with little restraint, and in a dogmatical tone, while he listened, as if with deference; now and then slyly insinuating rather than asserting his dissent, but contradicting nothing— It was near six O’Clock when he left me— Edward Wyer had been before, to pay his visit— Mrs Adams had in the Evening her weekly tea-party which was very numerously attended.

3. VI:Mr Sanford a Senator from New-York, came and introduced a young man of that City, by the name of Rhinelander, and another young man by the name of Jones, brought me a Letter of introduction. Captain O’Brien called at the Office, and Mr. Calhoun. I called at the President’s with the Report to him, the draft of a Message to the House of Representatives, and the copies of the documents to be sent with them— The House of Representatives, yesterday on the motion of Henry R. Storrs, a member from the State of New-York, passed a Resolution “that the Committee on the Expenditures of the Department of State be instructed, specially, to inquire whether any moneys have been disbursed through that Department, or authorized to be disbursed, on account of any salary or compensation to an Agent, or acting agent, or any person employed in that capacity on the part of the United States during the year 1820. under the sixth or seventh Articles of the late Treaty of Peace with Great-Britain; and if any moneys have been so paid, to inquire and report to the House, by authority of what Law, and by virtue and out of what appropriation the same has been paid.” This is a thrust in the dark at me as Secretary of State. There is of late years in the House of Representatives, a standing committee upon the Expenditures in each of the Executive Departments; consisting of
three members, appointed at the first Session of each Congress, for the whole term of the Congress. These Committees are in principle set as a Watch over the Heads of Departments; to guard against their wasting the public money; but hitherto I had heard nothing of the Committee upon the Department of State, except of its appointment— The Chairman of the Committee now was a Mr Peek, a Member from New-York who has not been here this Session— But this day, Storrs was appointed to supply his place— At the last Session of Congress the Appropriation for the Salary of an Agent to the Commission under the sixth and seventh Articles of the Treaty of Ghent, was struck out of the Estimates; Samuel Hawkins who had been the agent having resigned or been dismissed, and no other appointed in his place— JosephDelafield then applied to be allowed to perform the indispensable duties of Agent, for the same Salary which he had received as Secretary to the former agent, and the necessary additional expences. I was directed by the President to accept Delafield’s proposal, upon condition that the account of his compensation and expences should be sanctioned by the Commissioner, and come within the Appropriation for the year. Delafield’s Letter and my answer, were communicated to the House with the other papers, upon Mr Mallary’s call; and Storrs seems to think he has me upon the hip, for an expenditure without Law or appropriation— It happens that there is both Law and appropriation— For Delafield can receive nothing without the sanction of the Commissioner, which is authorized by the Treaty, and his payment is expressly limited to come within the appropriation of the year— Storrs is a federalist, of some talents and a handsome Speaker— He has been a member of three successive Congresses, which for a member from the State of New-York is very unusual; but having mistaken the sense of his Constituents on the Missouri questions, he will probably not be returned to the next Congress.— This prospect which he has of late distinctly foreseen has disconcerted all his expectations of public life, and produced effects upon his temper and habits unfavourable to his consideration and influence— He made a violent attack upon me in the Seminole-War debate in January 1819. but was afterwards on terms of good humour and politeness with me— He is now dissatisfied with himself and with all the world— This motion is probably made with a view to make a special scrutiny into the expences of the Department of State, and to signalize if he can any misapplication in it of public money. I trust he will be disappointed.

4. VII: I received this morning a Letter from John Gaillard, President pro Tempore of the Senate; informing me that he has received no list of the electoral votes for President and Vice-President and Vice-President, either by Mail or Messenger from the State of Mississippi; and referring to the Act of Congress of 1. March 1792 which requires that the electors in each State should make out and sign three certificates of their votes; one of which they are to send by special Messenger, and another by the Post Office to the President of the Senate at the Seat of Government: and the third is to be delivered to the Judge of District— The Act further directs that if neither of the certificates of Votes by Mail or Messenger from any State shall have been received at the Seat of Government on the first Wednesday in January, the Secretary of State shall send a special Messenger to the District Judge with whom the list shall have been deposited, who shall forthwith transmit the same to the Seat of Government— It became necessary to despatch this Messenger immediately. I called at the President’s to take his directions concerning it, and to enquire, if there was any person whom he would wish to have sent as the Messenger— He did not think of any— I mentioned to him young Breckenridge, which he approved; but doubted whether he was yet here— Mr Crawford, who was at the President’s named Radcliff, a young lawyer, who is an applicant at all the Departments for office— I went home, and upon enquiry of Johnson Hellen, found that Breckenridge was gone for New-Orleans— I therefore immediately sent for Radcliff who agreed to go, and for whom I immediately drew up a Letter of Instructions, and a Letter to that U.S. District judge in the State of Mississippi— He is to depart at 3. O’Clock to-morrow Morning— I this day received despatches from Mr Forsyth, announcing definitively the ratification, by the king of Spain, of the Florida Treaty; but there is with the Ratification a Correspondence between the Spanish Minister of foreign Affairs, Péréz de Castro and him, which gives him some uneasiness, and which yet leaves some
uncertainty upon the affair— The Cortes have in the most explicit manner declared null and void the grants to Alagon, Puñon Rostro and Vargas, but at the same time have recommended, an attempt to obtain some equivalent for this concession, by Negotiation— Perez de Castro after a Conference with Mr Forsyth on this subject wrote him a long Note, urging earnestly this demand, which Forsyth supposes will be renewed here, by General Vivés, when the ratified Treaty is transmitted to him— So that there are yet obstacles to be removed— Mr Stokes a Senator from North-Carolina called at the Office.

5. VI: The Spanish Minister, General Vivès called upon me this morning, and requested answers, to several Notes which he has addressed to me; two of which are upon the case of the Esperanza, a Spanish vessel taken upon a Slave-trading voyage, by the United States Sloop of War Cyane, Captain Trenchard, sent into New-York—one upon the case of a Spanish Consul at New-Orleans, named Villavaso, who has been arrested upon a civil process; and two upon the case of the French Ship Apollon, seized on the Spanish side of St. Mary’s river, for violation of our revenue Laws— A second case of a similar character has occurred; that of the Eugene, which after entering St. Mary’s river, was forced to go away— In these cases, Vivés said he was the more anxious to receive an answer, because he was much urged by Mr Roth, the Chargé d’Affaires from France— I told him that with regard to the cases of the Esperanza and the Consul, delays had occurred from the necessity of ascertaining facts, and of awaiting the judicial decisions— In the cases of the French vessels, I had waited in the hope of the ratification of the Florida Treaty. By that event the jurisdiction of both sides of St. Mary’s river would belong to the United States— The questions of right involved in the transactions relating to the Apollon and the Eugene, would cease to be important, and the unpleasant discussions likely to result from them, I hoped might be abridged— Should that discussion take place, I should be under the necessity of making serious complaint against two Spanish Officers; the Governor of East-Florida, for constituting a pretended Port where there was no settlement, and could be no honest trade; and the only possible object of which was to defraud the revenue of the United States: and the Spanish acting Consul at St. Mary’s, whose avowed object in all these transactions of which he had been the principal agent was to evade the Laws, and defraud the revenue of the Union. We were in possession of two private Letters written by him, disclosing the whole project, and proving that it was in substance a conspiracy against the Country where this man was residing under the protection of the Consular character— As in the event of the ratification of the Treaty the whole project would be at an end, I had hoped to be spared the necessity of discussing it, at-all; and wished him to assign this to his Government as the reason for delaying the answer to his Notes— He said that the Governor of East-Florida, had no authority to constitute the Port of St. Joseph, unless by a special power from the Governor General of Cuba— Whether Governor Coppinger had in this case such a power, he Vivés did not know— He had himself been surprized that Coppinger should have taken such a step precisely at the moment when the ratification of the Treaty was hourly expected, and had written to him and earnestly cautioned him against anything which should because of complaint to the United States. As to the Treaty, he had been assured by his Government that the ratification might be confidently expected, and he hoped he should speedily receive it by a special messenger. Mr Poletica likewise called upon me, and shewed me a communication which he had received from Count Bulgari, the Russian Chargé d’Affaires at Madrid; being copy of a Note from the Spanish Minister of foreign Affairs to him announcing the ratification by him of the Florida Treaty— I wrote the monthly despatch to R. Rush. Mr Delafield the acting Agent under the Commission upon the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty came, and renewed the request which he had already made by Letter, to be regularly attached to the Commission—
I mentioned to him the present state of this subject in Congress, upon the Resolutions of Mr Mallary and of Mr Storrs, to which is now added another offered by Mr Burwell of Virginia to pass an act for fixing the Salaries of the Commissioners and Agents under these Commissions— I told him it would be necessary to see what would be done upon these proceedings in Congress, before any thing further concerning his agency could be determined— I received a Letter of enquiries this day from Mr Mallary the Chairman of the committee on the documents sent with the Message— There was a Ball this Evening at Mr Gales’s which our young family attended, but neither Mrs Adams nor myself. It was intended for a twelfth Night party and given this Evening instead of tomorrow, because that being Saturday it was apprehended the festivities might encroach upon the Sunday— Miss Van Ness was the Queen of the Night and Mr B. L. Lear the King. The prerogative of this royalty is to give a similar party the next year.

6. VI:30. A Snow-Storm began about 8 O’Clock this Morning, which continued the whole day— At the Office, I was occupied in preparing a despatch to A. Gallatin with which I send copies of all the papers relating to the seizure of the French ship Apollon, and the case of the Eugene— Mr Roth, the Charge d’Affaires from France has written several Notes upon this subject, the last of which enclosed a protest by the Captain of the Eugene; couched in language so insulting to this Government that I was somewhat angered— I drafted an answer to Roth’s Note, and sent it to the President for consideration— The President wrote me that Roth’s Note deserved every thing that I had said of it in my answer, but advised that I should only communicate verbally with Roth on the subject, and wait for the arrival of Mr Hyde de Neuville, to treat of it amicably, and to give friendly explanations to the French Government, through Mr Gallatin— I therefore withheld my Letter to Roth, and answered him thus through Gallatin— Dined at Mr Crawford’s, with a company of about twenty men, Foreign Legations, and members of Congress— No Ladies and Mrs Crawford was not present. We made a short dinner of it, and I came home the Snow-Storm still raging. Spent the remainder of the Evening at cards with the young people.

7. VI:30.John Linn, a member of the House of Representatives, from the State of New-Jersey died yester day before yesterday, and was buried yesterday in the midst of the Snow-Storm— There are several other members of Congress very ill; one of whom Mr De Witt of New-York is believed to be past recovery. There is no small alarm among the members, at this extraordinary thinning of their ranks by death; and as there is no deadly epidemic prevailing among the residents in the City, there have arisen suspicions that there is some pernicious infection in the mode of heating, or some defect in the ventilation of the Halls at the Capitol; especially of the House of Representatives— The Snow-storm continued through the last Night, and subsided about eight O’Clock this Morning; leaving about a foot deep of Snow; not much drifted; the gale not having been very violent— With the boys, I waded through the Snow; and attended Church at the Capitol— The preacher was a Mr. M’Ilvaine, a very young man of great promise, settled recently at an Episcopalian Church in Georgetown— His text was from Matthew XVI:26. “For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?” The Sermon was well written and eloquent; but much more in the enthusiastic manner of the Methodists than in the usual cool, didactic and argumentative style of episcopalian Clergyman— The vehement, passionate and terrifying tone of Oratory have of late however, been much practised by the Episcopalians in our Southern Countries; and with them they have resumed the rigorous Calvinistic doctrines of election and atonement, regeneration and reprobation, which the Church of England had long discarded— They have been driven to this resource by the desertion of their followers— Fear and Hope are the two pillars upon which all religious Faith is built— But Fear is an instrument of Necessity— Hope is the creature of contingency— Fear flies to a refuge— Hope is always attended with doubt, and conscious of its own delusions. Fear is therefore always a more efficacious agent than hope, and has far more powerful operation upon religious faith. There is another reason for the new kindling fervours of the Southern Episcopalians; who are now almost all educated at Princeton College— The teachers at that Institution, are
of the most straitest sect of the Calvinists, and men of considerable ability— M’Ilvaine is from that school, and a native of the State of New-Jersey— He expatiated with great effort of pathos upon the importance of the Soul, and the infinite danger of its loss; but he did not undertake to explain what the Soul is— That was above his reach— I returned home immediately after the service. Mr Gaillard, the President of the Senate, and Mr H. G. Otis, the Senator from Massachusetts with his son William, a Classmate of my son George had called to visit at the House, before I came in— William Otis is here upon a short visit during the vacation, and has just arrived.

8. VI: The temperature of the atmosphere had been unusually cold during the Snow-Storm, the thermometer of Fahrenheit having ranged from 23 to 26 and back to 24 the day and Evening of Saturday. Yesterday morning it cleared away at 28. fell to 24 at noon to 14 at nine in the Evening and when I rose this morning was at 4. above 0. corresponding to 12. 4/9 below 0 of Reaumur— It rose almost to the freezing point in the middle of the day; and fell only to 24 again this evening. Mr Clagett the member of the House of Representatives from New-Hampshire, came to the Office with a Letter from George Sullivan Attorney General of New-Hampshire, certifying as his opinion that Daniel Humphreys the District Attorney is not competent to perform the duties of that Office. Claggett’s object being to obtain the office in favour of his Son. I am not much edified with the delicacy of this procedure— I was occupied at the Office, in drafting an answer to a Letter from Lewis Williams, Chairman of the Committee of Claims of the House of Representatives upon the petition of Captain O’Brien— I had already answered him once, but he sent me back the papers with a second Letter of enquiries— I am also very much engaged in the Morning, by an examination of the Virginian Statutes at large—

9. VI:45.Captain O’Brien was at the Office, to urge the hastening of my answer, to the Letter of the Chairman of the Committee of Claims upon his petition. I told him it was ready and would be sent to Mr Williams to-morrow— I had also visits at the Office, from Mr Parrott, a Senator from New-Hampshire, Mr Dana, a Senator from Connecticut, and Mr Canning, the British Minister. Parrott came upon the subject of the appointment of a District Attorney in New-Hampshire. He wishes the re-appointment of Humphreys, who though near eighty years of age, is not he says, so incompetent as he has been represented— The duties of the Office indeed at this time, and probably during peace will continue to be few and unimportant— Parrott gave me much information concerning Humphreys, who is an elder brother of the late General David Humphreys— He has certain peculiar religious opinions, and the indigence of his old age has been occasioned by the profusion of his charitable beneficence in younger life. But Parrott said if Humphreys must be dropped, at all Events he hoped young Clagett would not be nominated in his place; for Clagett had neither talents nor integrity— He was at the very bottom of the Bar of New-Hampshire; and his conduct towards Mr Plumer whose daughter he had married had been shameful. When Plumer was Governor of New-Hampshire, Clagett presuming upon his affinity to him, had importuned him to appoint, his, Clagett’s father, the present member of Congress a Judge of the Supreme Court of the State— Governor Plumer had very properly resisted this importunity, upon which Clagett had commenced a violent and abusive attack upon him in the Newspapers, and had continued it at various times through the whole course of Plumer’s administration— All intercourse between the families had consequently been broken off, and Plumer when at Portsmouth never would enter Clagett’s house; even while his daughter was living— She is now dead— Parrott declared that young Clagett’s character was so notoriously discreditable; that he was surprized there were found any persons of reputation, who would recommend him. Sullivan’s only reason he though must have been because Clagett had read Law in his Office— Mr Dana is Chairman of a Committee of the Senate who are making enquiries with a view to reduce and retrench the public expeditures— He has been obtaining abstracts of the Accounts shewing the amounts of expenditures
in the several Executive Departments at various periods of time in 1800. 1808. 1816 and 1820. This disposition for retrenchment has arisen from the low state of the revenue, and the distressed condition of the country. The Spirit as is natural prevails strongly throughout the Union, and is so predominant in Congress, that nothing would stand before it, but for advice which has been given them to let their economy begin at home— The Legislatures of Rhode-Island and New-Hampshire passed resolutions recommending to their Senators, and members of the House in Congress, to endeavour to obtain a Law to reduce the pay of Members of Congress to six dollars a day, and six dollars for every twenty-miles of travel— At the Commencement of the Session, the late Mr Burrill in the Senate, and Mr Eddy in the House of Representatives, members from Rhode-Island offered Resolutions, for such reductions, as were recommended by the Legislature of their own State, and the way they were met was to connect them with plans of general reduction of the Salaries of all Officers in the Executive Departments. In the Senate, on motion of Mr Dana, a substitute was adopted instead of Burrill’s Resolution, and a Committee of five was appointed to inquire into the propriety of reducing the pay of the members of Congress; and also the allowances of all Executive Officers, with leave to report by Bill, or otherwise— Dana is the Chairman of this Committee, and is making the above-mentioned enquiries with a view to the Report— Eddy’s Resolution fared still worse in the House of Representatives. The House refused to consider it; but sweeping propositions of universal retrenchment, in the army, navy fortifications, and executive offices took their places— Dana himself does not incline to the reduction of any of the expences of the mere administration of the Government, but he is not prepared to meet the tide of popular sentiment by direct opposition. His path is by winding Stairs— Mr Canning came to speak of the papers communicated to the House of Representatives, by the President, with his Message relative to the Negotiations concerning the Slave trade— There was one passage in a despatch from me to R. Rush, which I was aware would when published be displeasing to the British Government—it was a reflection somewhat pointed, at the principle in the Treaty between Great-Britain and the Netherlands, that the Cruizers for Slave-traders, of each Nation should be authorized to search vessels of the other even under convoy of armed vessels of their own— Canning alluded to it in general terms, intimating that he could have wished that it had not been included in the communication to Congress— As a Letter of Instruction from this Government to its own Minister, he had nothing to say of it; but as it was no part of the Communications which had passed between the two Governments, it did not seem he said to be required by the Call from the House, and containing something like censure on the British Government, might have been omitted from Papers communicated to Congress for publication. I told him that the Call of the House included whatever had been done, by direction of the President in this Negotiation; of which the Instruction to Mr Rush was a very essential part— That I was not aware of any censure in the paper to which he alluded, upon the British Government; the allusion was only to an important difference of principle between them and us— And the occasion was such as required that we should be very explicit in the avowal of our principles— I could assure him there was nothing offensive in the intention— He then observed that among the papers communicated he had observed that the addresses from both Houses of Parliament to the King, requesting him further to negotiate with the United States for the suppression of the Slave-trade, were not included— It had escaped my recollection that copies of these addresses had ever been received— I told Mr Canning that I thought they had not— The substance of them had been reported in a despatch from Mr Rush which is one of the papers sent with the Message to the House of Representatives; but the Copies of the Addresses themselves I believed had not been received. He said he would send me copies of them to-morrow and I promised him that a Supplementary Message should be sent with them— Immediately after he left me, I examined myself the whole file of Rush’s despatches, and very soon found the one enclosing the copies of the addresses. It had been overlooked
by Mr Brent the Chief Clerk of the Department, in the search which I had altogether relied upon him to make of the papers to be sent in answer to the call of the House— I immediately directed copies of them to be made, and as the documents with the message have not yet been printed in pamphlet, I desired Mr Brent, if the Speaker of the House would consent, that they should be sent immediately to the Printers, and added as part of the Documents annexed to the Message. This accident is one of those which many times have happened from the complicated cause of my own inattention, Brent’s ineptitude, and the want of method in the arrangement of business, and disposal of papers in the Department. Every such instance of defective memory in myself, brings with it humiliating reflections upon my own infirmity, while conscious of that, let it at least make me sensible of the indulgence due to others. I ought not to have forgotten that these papers had been received from Mr Rush— I ought to have examined the whole file of Rush’s despatches myself, for the documents to be sent with the message.— We had this Evening our weekly tea-party which was fully attended; but Mrs Adams who has been these two or three days quite unwell, after making an effort to receive the company was obliged to leave the drawing-room when they came, and retired to bed— The noise of the company, of the music, and the dancing in the adjoining chamber, and the room beneath her, aggravated excessively her complaint which was a nervous head ache, and after the company were gone, she was extremely ill.

10. VII:Mrs Adams continued very severely ill all last Night and the whole of this day. Coll. R. M. Johnson the Senator from Kentucky, called at the Office, to recommend his brother for the appointment of a judge in the territory of Arkansas; in the room of a man named Thompson of the State of Ohio, who received a temporary Commission during the recess of the Senate, and who neither resigns it, nor goes to the territory. It being a judicial office, the President doubts whether in the Spirit of the Constitution he can with propriety nominate another person; thereby virtually removing from office a person, commissioned as a judge— This scruple is honourable to the President, but I think his power to nominate another person unquestionable— In the Spirit of the Constitution, it ought to be exercised with great reserve, and only in extraordinary cases— The President will refer the question to the Attorney General for his opinion— Mr. Wilmot who is attached as a Secretary to the British Legation brought me from Mr Canning the copies of the Addresses from both Houses of Parliament to the King, recommending further negotiation with France and the United States for the suppression of the Slave Trade; but I told him that the copies which were transmitted by Mr Rush had been found, and would immediately be communicated to the House of Representatives. W. Seaton one of the Printers of Congress was here; and told me that the pamphlet containing the papers sent before was already printed, and the Speaker of the House thought no others could be received, without another message— I therefore drafted a Supplementary Report to the President, to go with the Supplementary Message. Baron Stackelberg was here two or three days since, to complain that in a published official return from the Register of the Treasury of the trade of the United States, with the several parts of Europe, that with Denmark and Norway had been presented in connection together, there being at this time no political union between Denmark and Norway; but Norway forming a part of the dominions of the King of Sweden— I told him this had been altogether accidental, and merely the habitual use of a long established Classification at the Treasury of the European Countries, for the purpose of making these returns— But I requested him to write me a Note on the Subject, and promised that the form of the returns should be rectified, for the future.— This incident is one of many which have occurred shewing how extremely sensitive king Charles JohnBernadotte is, with regard to his right and title to Norway.

11. VII:R. W. Meade of Philadelphia, a man, who has been of great notoriety in the course of our controversies with Spain, came this morning and introduced himself to me at the Office; saying that he was the bearer of the Florida Treaty, ratified by the King of Spain. He then took from his pocket a large packet addressed to the Spanish Minister, General Vivés, and said that was the Treaty: and that he, Meade had received it from the Messenger, who had brought it from Madrid. He was going with it to General Vivés, but had determined to come and shew it to me, and give me the first notice of its being here— There were circumstances which led me to suspect that Mr Meade was mistaken, but as he was an entire stranger to me, and a few hours would ascertain the fact, I said nothing to him of my suspicions— He asked me if his claim was provided for in the Treaty; and said that it was of infinite importance for him to know immediately, in order that if it was not, he might without delay report to the Spanish Government to obtain payment of it— I said that this question had been put to me from many other claimants, and I had invariably declined answering it, because whether any particular claim was or was not embraced by the provisions of the Treaty was to be decided by the Commissioners, upon the terms of the Treaty itself, which must speak for and explain itself— My opinion upon it would go for nothing— All I could say to him was that I supposed his claim was included among those provided for by the Treaty— After Meade left me I called at the President’s and told him what Meade had said of his being the bearer of the ratified Treaty— But I requested the President not to mention it to any person; for I did not believe it, and if it should go forth as a positive fact from the Administration, and afterwards prove untrue, it would cast a ridicule upon the Administration itself. Mr Delafield called, and told me that he had conversed both with Mr Storrs and Mr Mallary upon their Resolutions concerning the Ghent Treaty Commissions. That they had both declared themselves perfectly satisfied of the propriety of his appointment, and with the allowance made to him for the service— I said that Mr Mallary’s Resolution did not appear to bear upon this point; but if Mr Storrs as Chairman of the Committee of the House of Representatives, upon the expenditures in the Department of State, would Report to the House the opinion which he had expressed to Delafield, all would be right— I had been expecting to hear from Mr Storrs, since his appointment on this Committee—but hitherto without effect— Mr William Allen Deas, paid me a visit on his way from Philadelphia, to the Western Country, where he now resides— In the year 1794, I had known him as Secretary to Mr Thomas Pinckney then our Minister in London— In October 1795 I found him again as Chargé d’Affaires at London, and upon Mr Pinckney’s return from his special Mission to Madrid, he resumed the character of his Secretary— I left him in London, May 1796. then about to return with Mr Pinckney to this Country— Since then I have never seen him till this day— He was then a young, gay, and fashionable man— Twenty-five years have drawn furrows upon his face— He is now a plain, grave and elderly man. These transitions from youth to old age, always seem instantaneous on meeting after a lapse of many years a person whom I have formerly known— Nothing so forcibly brings home to the mind, the operation of time and human mutability. Memory retains of persons the impression left upon it when they were last seen— Time accomplishes a Metamorphosis, which we can scarcely realize but by the testimony of the senses— I received some months since from Mr Deas, a Letter, soliciting my aid in behalf of his son, to obtain for him a warrant of Midshipman in the Navy. He is to proceed upon his journey to-morrow, and dined with me this day, together with Messrs.James Barbour, Macon, Ruggles, and Talbot, Senators, Allen of Massachusetts, Bloomfield, Brevard, Burton, Dane, Darlington, Richards, and S. Smith of Maryland, members of the House of Representatives, and Solomon Sibley, Delegate from the Territory of Michigan. Mr Calhoun the Secretary of War, Mr Hugh Nelson, member of the house from Virginia, Mr Bates, delegate from the territory of Arkansas, and Scott from that of Missouri, were invited but did not come. Calhoun and Nelson accepted, and we
waited till past six O’Clock for Calhoun— Nelson sent an apology, which I received as we were going to sit down at table— Bates and Scott sent excuses— The dinner was dull— No Ladies at Table; Mrs Adams being yet confined the whole day to her bed, and to my great anxiety, alarmingly ill— The latter part of this Evening however she was much recovered.

12. VII:Mr Calhoun called this morning at my house, and apologized for having missed dining with us yesterday; he had forgotten the day of the invitation, and did not discover the mistake, until last Evening after having dined at home— He also enquired if I had any further accounts from Spain— I told him of Meade’s visit and assertion yesterday, which last, having heard nothing from General Vives, I now totally disbelieved. On going to the Office I received a Letter from Meade himself; acknowledging the mistake, and that General Vives had this day informed him that the despatch of which he had been the bearer did not contain the Treaty. He represents himself to have been led into the error by the assurances of several Spanish Consuls and Agents. Of all the transactions in which I ever was concerned this Negotiation is the most treacherous—not a step of it can be taken without meeting with delusion and fraud— General Mason of Georgetown, was likewise at the Office. He is Agent for many of the claimants for whom provision is made in the Treaty, and as there is now no doubt of its ratification, he came to ask permission to examine the vouchers and documents transmitted heretofore to the Department, in the cases for which he is agent, to which I assented— Our young men this day dined with T. Cook, and Fanny Johnson at Captain Thompson’s, where the boys also passed the Evening.

13. VI:Captain O’Brien called at the Office— He has not yet obtained a Report from the Committee of Claims upon his petition— The Ship he says is a ground on the Missouri bar, and God knows when or how she will be got off— They have been three days debating in the House of Representatives, whether an entry upon their Journals should be that Mr Lowndes presented three Memorials of the Legislature “of Missouri,” or “of the State of Missouri”—and have taken five times the yeas and nays, upon questions arising from the debate. The Clerk had made up the Journal with the words “State of Missouri” the Speaker had erased the words “the State of”— Cobb of Georgia, moved to amend the Journal, by reinserting the words “the State of” the vote on this question was 76 to 76. and was decided only by the casting vote of the Speaker himself. Then there were motions to insert the words “the territory of” [“]the late territory of” and finally a string of Resolutions offered by R. R. Reid of Georgia, declaring the rasures made by the Speaker to be alterations, and not corrections of the Journal. These are all ebullitions from the heated temper of the parties. The actual condition of Missouri is neither that of a State or a Territory; but in the very process of the Metamorphosis— The Chrysalis between the egg and the butterfly— Mr W. Lee called at the Office, and shewed me a Letter from Tench Coxe to him, relative to my expected Report on Weights and Measures. Mr Amado Grehon the Chargé d’Affaires from Portugal, came to take leave, intending to return in a few days to Philadelphia, where he habitually resides. I received a second Letter from R. C. Mallary, Chairman of the Committee on the Ghent Treaty Commissions. The former Letter was of the 6th. instt. containing several enquiries, to answer which rendered a thorough examination of the records concerning the Commissions under Mr Jay’s Treaty of 1794, as well as a revisal of all that has been done under the present Commissions— Many papers were also to be copied and sent to the Committee— I was not yet prepared to answer the Letter, of the 5th when that of this day came, referring to it, and expressing an apprehension that I had not received it— I was at the President’s, and mentioned these enquiries to him— There was an agreement signed by him and by A. S. J. Baker, at the Exchange of the Ratifications of the Treaty of Ghent, respecting the Salaries of the Commissioners; but it was not explicit as to their amount; which
is precisely the question now to be determined— The President’s recollection is that it was understood the Salaries of the Commissioners should be the same as were those of the Commissioners under the Treaty of 1794—but under that Treaty there were three Commissions and the Salaries of the Commissioners were not all the same— There is therefore a difficulty in the subject not easily to be removed. An incident occurred this evening in my family which gave me great concern and vexation. Mrs Adams yet not wholly recovered from her severe illness, had been however well enough to dine with us. After dinner between 8 and 9 in the Evening, we were sitting together by the fire— I was reading a Newspaper. Fanny Johnson and Mary Hellen, with our Sons George and John were playing Cards, when there was a loud knock at our Street door, and a note was brought in and delivered to George, with word left by the servant who brought it that it required immediate answer— George immediately left the table, called Johnson Hellen out of the room and after a few minutes went out of the house alone— Johnson Hellen came back, and I enquired whom the Note was from— He said from Mr Martin— I asked where George was gone— He said to Strother’s. I was deeply agitated, but suppressed every appearance of emotion. Mrs Adams controuled her feelings also; Johnson Hellen took George’s Cards and the game continued. In about half an hour, George came back— His mother shortly afterwards went to her chamber, where she sent for him, and he told her what had passed between him and Martin— She asked me then to converse with him and advise him— I called him to my chamber, where he first intreated me not to interfere authoritatively between him and Martin, and then shewed me Martin’s Note, which was in these words;—“Mr R. N. Martin solicits the company of Mr G. W. Adams, at Mr Strother’s on business, and presumes, if he be not engaged the pleasure will be granted without delay.— Saturday Evening.” George said that on receiving this Note his first impression was to ask Johnson Hellen to go with him— But on reflection he had concluded to go alone, and unarmed— At Strother’s on asking for Martin he had been shewn to a private room, where he was alone, with a horse-whip on the table— To shew him that he had noticed this Circumstance, George said to him, “I see you have been riding.”— Martin then after some formal civilities said that he had it from the most unquestionable authority that George had told a Lady that a Gentleman had assured him that Martin had told that Gentleman, that the Lady was engaged to be married to him—Martin— That it was scarcely possible for him to believe this; but if it was so he should expect from George, either an apology or the satisfaction of a Gentleman— George said he had answered him—Mr Martin the Lady of whom you speak is Miss Fanny Johnson, and the Gentleman is Mr H. G. Otis— I shall make you no apology, for I have done no wrong— I never said what you say you have been told I did. I never said to any one that I had been told you said Miss Johnson was engaged to you; but in casual conversation at Mr Gales’s, the question being asked if she was, I said that from your conduct towards her I supposed she was—and afterwards one Evening at my father’s, Mr Otis having observed that it was reported there was such an engagement, I said I believed there was not— Miss Mary Hellen who was present said she suspected there was; on which Mr Otis asked whether you said there was; Miss Hellen answered no. These are the facts, and for this I have no apology to make; and shall make none— Upon which Martin said as to any inference which any person chose to draw from his conduct, he took no offence at that— He was entirely satisfied with the explanation George had given him, which was entirely conformable to Mr Otis’s statement of the circumstances to him— That he was going in a day or two to Baltimore, and perhaps might in the interval see Miss Johnson again— He wished George to consider nothing as having passed between them; but in a very emphatic, and assuming tone had requested him to spare the feelings of Miss Johnson, upon which George answered that he should “treat Miss Johnson with the respect due from him to a person who was under his father’s roof;” and left him— George then observed that if Fanny Johnson had reported to Martin, what he had alledged, it was in the first place not true; and in the second, no very becoming thing on her part; as she could not be ignorant of its tendency to breed a quarrel— He should ask her to-morrow Morning whether she ever had told Martin, as he represented it, and if she had, and should persist in the assertion, or equivocate in the answer, this affair must go further. I told him, that it would be better for some third person to ascertain from Fanny Johnson, whether she had told Martin what he had asserted— I said I was glad as it had turned out that he went immediately, alone and unarmed
on receiving the note from Martin; but that Martin’s mode of proceeding was in every respect improper— That there was a studied ostentation in sending the Note, with a demand by the servant of an immediate answer; which he knew would in all probability be delivered in the presence of the family. He knew it could not but alarm the female part of the family— It looked as if he hoped I should interfere to forbid George from answering his call, that he might afterwards turn it to the account of his own Spirit, and against George. But his sending for George to come to him, in the Night, to a tavern, to give him an explanation, or fight him, was a piece of unparalleled insolence— I was glad that George had taken his own course without consulting me; but that if on receiving the Note he had asked my advice, I should have recommended to him to answer, that for any business which Mr Martin might wish to transact with Mr G. W. Adams, the latter would be happy to receive him at his residence in his fathers house, or at Mr Martin’s option, at any other suitable place, in the presence of a mutual friend— If this affair should proceed further I enjoined upon George, not to go to Martin again alone, nor to have any conversation with him, but in the presence of a third person, and a fourth if Martin chose— On leaving George to retire to bed, I found that Mary Hellen had been taken suddenly ill, and after a long fainting fit, was in bed with severe cramps, a high fever, and delirious. Dr Huntt was immediately sent for, and soon after came. Mrs Adams was up with her till two in the Morning, when her illness abated and she fell asleep— Fanny Johnson was with her.

14. VII:15. I told Mrs Adams this morning that the first thing to be done was to ascertain from Fanny Johnson, whether she had told Martin, that George had said to her, what Martin had alledged— She denied explicitly and distinctly having told him so. I then drew up the question in writing, and gave the paper to Mrs Adams, to give to Fanny, with a request that she would answer it, at the bottom of the paper, and sign her name. I attended Church at the Capitol, and heard Mr Ryland, the Chaplain of the Senate. I then called at Claxton’s on Mr Mallary, and mentioned to him the reasons why I had not yet answered his Letter of the 5th. and to tell him that I should answer it as soon as the copies could be made out of the documents to be sent with the answer. He said he had written his second Letter, only from an apprehension that I might not have received the first— I saw at Claxton’s several others of the members who lodge there, and heard of the illness of several others— Meech of Vermont has a fever. De Witt of New-York lies yet, of very doubtful recovery— Overstreet of South Carolina, is dangerously bruised in the head by the oversetting of a Carriage; and Jones of Tennessee has a hurt by falling after dinner into a cellar— Returning home, I called on the way at W. S. Smith’s, and saw his wife— When I came home on going in to the parlour I found Martin, with Fanny Johnson, sitting in tête à tête, and from the appearance of her eyes she had been in tears— I took a seat, and after a few minutes waiting, Martin rose, and said, “Miss Johnson, I shall see you again before I go— In the meantime, I pray you to be assured, that whatever may happen, I shall always entertain for you the sentiments of a friend and a brother.” As he was going to the door, I said to him; Mr Martin, it is with extreme reluctance, and with great pain that I feel myself compelled to say to you what I now do— If you have any further conversation to hold with Miss Johnson, I have to request it may not be in my house— He said there were circumstances of which he hoped that when I came to be informed, I should be induced not to repeat that request— I replied that there was no circumstance could justify the intrusion upon the privacy and the outrage upon the peace of my family, by the manner in which he had sent a Summons to my Son, to go to him at a tavern last Evening— He said, surely his proceeding towards my Son had been both respectful and polite— He had merely solicited, the pleasure of his Company, if he was not engaged— Sir, said I, this is not a case of special pleading at a County Court— With any question between you and my Son, I have no concern; my Sons conduct must depend upon himself— It is your calling him out of my house in a manner, which in its nature must spread alarm and consternation among the women
which is offensive to me, and so offensive that I can take no pleasure in receiving at my house any person, capable of such conduct— He said no more, but went off— I found afterwards to my great surprize that Fanny Johnson instead of immediately answering the written paper, which I had left, had requested that Martin might be sent for to have this private interview with him. She afterwards wrote at the bottom of the paper that she did not tell Martin that which Martin had imputed to him, and signed her name to the declaration. Dr Thornton spent part of the Evening with us. Mary Hellen was better, but still confined the whole day to her bed.

15. VIII: Having had no sleep the night before last, the last Night was the longer, and for many months I have not risen so late as this morning. Mr Dickinson called here and introduced a young man from New-York, by the name of Hone.— While he was here, Mr H. G. Otis called, but supposing me to be engaged, left word that he wished to see me on the part of Mr Martin— As I was going out, I met at the door Mr Bailey, with a young man from Philadelphia, by the name of Rogers, whom he introduced— I went with George to the Senate chamber, to see Mr Otis— He was engaged in business there, but told me that he would call on me at the Department, after the adjournment of the Senate, which he did— He then said that Martin had called upon him yesterday, apparently in great irritation, and complained that I had forbidden him my house; and had requested him to see me, and to assure me of the propriety of his conduct. He had related to him what had passed the Evening before, between him and my Son George— Told him that he had been perfectly satisfied with George’s explanation and had considered it as an affair entirely settled— He had therefore been astonished at the offence which I had taken, and had wished Mr Otis to say to me, that Martin’s conduct had only been such as the vindication of his own honour required— He said that it had been his intention to treat my Son George with the utmost civility, and delicacy— That the note he had written to him was in the most respectful and friendly language, and that his motive in sending for George to meet him alone at Strother’s was precisely to avoid every appearance of formality; and to confine his request for an explanation, entirely between themselves. Otis then proceeded to tell me of his acquaintance with Martin, who lodges and messes at the same house with him at Georgetown— Martin he said was first introduced to him by Mr Goldsborough formerly a Senator from Maryland, and a relation of Martin’s— On his coming here this winter, Otis had heard that he had come in pursuit of a young Lady, whom her friends had sent here to be out of his way— He had observed that at one of Mrs Adams’s weekly parties, Mr Martin did not come—that at a subsequent one he proposed to come, and did come with him; not without some apprehension on Otis’s part, that he might be thought by us to be introduced by him— Afterwards the incidents occurred at Gales’s and at my house, which gave rise to this affair with George and which Otis related to the minutest point exactly as George had told them to me— But last Saturday Otis said, Martin had come to him in a state of high excitement and told him he had been informed that my Son George had reported his having been told by Mr Otis, that Martin had asserted to him that there was an engagement of marriage between Miss Johnson and himself. Otis said he had told Martin he was sure there must be some mistake in the matter— He had never said so to my Son, and he was confident George never had reported from him, what he had not said— And he had then told Martin the incidents which did occur, and from which this misunderstanding appeared to have arisen, as he now told them to me. Martin had then left him, and yesterday came to him again with his new complaint— He seemed to hope that I should upon being informed of all the Circumstances, acquit him of any intention of disrespect to me, and revoke the interdiction to him of my house. I told Mr Otis that I was disposed to make every proper allowance, for the excesses of a young man who appeared to be frantic with passion. But the peace, and quiet and health of my family had been too grossly outraged by Martin, to be forgiven on a mere declaration by him that he intended no disrespect— As to his call for an explanation upon my Son, I had told him I should not interpose in that— But in the first place the young Lady herself explicitly denies, not only that George ever said to her what Martin called upon him to explain, but that she ever told Martin, that George had made such a report to her. George therefore had never said any thing which
Martin had any right to call upon him to explain— Martin had done him precisely the injury which he had complained of having received from him. He had imputed to him a false report, upon allegations themselves false— And as to his forms of proceeding; his plea of polite language was ridiculous— I repeated the terms of the Note—the summons upon business, and without delay; the direct intimation to him at Strother’s, with a horse-whip on the table, that he had it from the most unquestionable authority that George had said so and so—and if he had that he must retract it or fight him— Here was an avowed unequivocal, contingent challenge—given upon false pretences—and sent in a manner, as if purposely intended to alarm my whole family— I was not much versed in the forms appropriate to the code of honourable murder, but of this I was sure; they never authorized a Gentleman to send for another to come to him in the Night at a tavern, alone to give him an explanation, or to fight him— As to the report that Fanny Johnson had been sent by her friends to my house to keep her out of Martin’s way, it was quite groundless. She was here at the earnest invitation of Mrs Adams, and myself; being an orphan Grand-daughter of the late Governor Thomas Johnson, of Fredericktown, Maryland, and daughter to a first Cousin of my wife’s— Martin had visited at my house, as many other Strangers do, in the Winter, and had been invited to Mrs. Adams’s weekly parties. After what had taken place, his company at my house could no longer be acceptable; and as to his assuming to enjoin upon my son George to spare the feelings of Miss Johnson, in my opinion he would have been better employed, in enjoining it more effectually upon himself— Otis said he had suggested himself to Martin, that delicacy to the young Lady would not consist in making her a subject of public talk— That the circumstances which I had mentioned presented a case very materially different from that stated by Martin— He understood that I would not re-admit Martin to my house, but upon his acknowledgment that he had been wrong. He, Otis could therefore no longer with any usefulness interfere in the affair— Martin had asked him for a certificate of the propriety of his conduct, but he should now excuse himself from taking any further part whatever in the transaction— And with this he left me— I received a Letter from Lewis Williams Chairman of the Committee of Claims, asking further explanations upon the subject of Captain O’Brien’s case— Mrs. W. S. Smith dined with us. Mary Hellen is recovering, but does not yet leave her chamber.

16. VII:Mr John G. Jackson, whom I knew formerly as a member of Congress from Virginia, and who is now the District judge of the Western District of Virginia called at my house this morning.— He is here on a visit of private business— Mr Hutchins G. Burton, a member of Congress from North Carolina, came to the Office, with papers relating to a claim of one of his constituents upon the British Government; either for services during the seven years War; or as a loyalist during that of our Revolution— Burton wished Mr Rush to be requested to make all necessary enquiries to ascertain the circumstances amount, and present state of this claim. He said he felt some awkwardness, at having any agency to support a claim for services against our own cause in the War of the Revolution; but that was now so long past, that it might be overlooked; and as the man was actually one of his Constituents, he had a right to any proper assistance that he could give him, to obtain his lawful claims even upon the British Government— I thought the better of Mr Burton, both for his scruple, and for his solution of it. Mr Richard Cranch Norton came relative to the settlement of an account of one of his brothers, who was in the army, and is dead— I was engaged in answering the Letter from Lewis Williams on O’Brien’s claim, and one from General Samuel Smith Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means— He enquires whether an appropriation to pay for a third picture of Coll Trumbull’s may not be dispensed with for the present year— And also whether the appropriation for an outfit for a Minister to Rio de Janeiro may not also be now postponed, especially as
there is no Portuguese Minister here; the Abbe Correa having sailed for Europe last November. This is a part of the system of retrenchment which is so predominant in Congress, upon every article of expenditure which does not touch the pay of the members themselves.— I am answering General S. Smith that both items named by him; may without expected material injury, be omitted from the appropriations of the present year— But that if that for the Minister’s outfit be struck out, there should be substituted one for a Charge d’Affaires. Mrs Adams had this Evening her weekly tea-party, which was very fully attended.

17. VI:30. I called this Morning at the Navy Office, where I saw Mr Thompson the Secretary, and Mr. Homans the Chief Clerk of the Department— It was to present a Bill of Exchange, for Mr Edward Cruft of Boston— He was anxious to obtain payment of it by anticipation; but this cannot be made until the navy appropriation Bill of the year shall have passed in Congress. Mr Canning called upon me at the Office, to have what he called a little gossiping conversation with me; but he stayed with me at least three full hours and at last after it was nearly dark, drawing out his watch, he exclaimed, “God bless me, ’tis near six O’Clock, and I have invited a large party to dine with me at five— I believe you must offend me.” Our conversation had been upon a great variety of topics, political and literary; but not upon any thing of business— As on other occasions I gave him with more freedom than caution my own opinions, while he was exceedingly reserved and discreet in the expression of his own— There is danger to a man in my station in holding such conversations; yet I do not even upon such occasions speak without motive. As I know that the substance of all that I say upon political topics will be reported to the Government of the man to whom I speak. I express such opinions, as being really mine, may so far as they can possibly have any influence, promote the interest of my Country, or the cause of truth, virtue and liberty— The danger is two-fold; first of being misunderstood; and secondly of being misrepresented; and it would perhaps be wiser, to keep all foreign Ministers more at a distance, and talk with them upon nothing but business, or the weather— George was unwell, and confined to the house— The other boys and Fanny Johnson spent the Evening at Mr T. Munroe’s. Mr Joseph G. Cogswell, and August Thorndike brought me Letters of introduction yesterday, from MrIsrael Thorndike of Boston— And Mr Van Lennep brought one from Mr. Gallatin at Paris— Cogswell is a young man who has been travelling several years in Europe, as the companion and semi-preceptor of young Thorndike— Cogswell has literature and some talents, apparently with a quantum sufficit of self-conceit— Van Lennep is a native of Smyrna, belonging to a low dutch family and commercial house there, and is very desirous of obtaining the appointment of American Consul at that place— These Gentlemen were all at our party last Evening.
